title: Salomon Cross Hike GTX Review: The Ultimate Hiking Boot Guide 2025
description: Comprehensive Salomon Cross Hike GTX review based on real-world testing. Discover pros, cons, performance analysis, and user feedback for these versatile hiking boots.
head:
<meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Salomon Cross Hike GTX Review: The Ultimate Hiking Boot Guide 2025</title>
    <meta name="description" content="Comprehensive Salomon Cross Hike GTX review based on real-world testing. Discover pros, cons, performance analysis, and user feedback for these versatile hiking boots.">
    <link href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/tailwindcss@2.2.19/dist/tailwind.min.css" rel="stylesheet">
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@fortawesome/fontawesome-free@6.4.0/css/all.min.css">
    <script type="application/ld+json">
    {
      "@context": "https://schema.org",
      "@type": "BlogPosting",
      "headline": "Salomon Cross Hike GTX Review: The Ultimate Hiking Boot Guide 2025",
      "description": "Comprehensive review of the Salomon Cross Hike GTX hiking boots based on real-world testing, user feedback, and expert analysis.",
      "author": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Trail Explorer Team"
      },
      "datePublished": "2025-01-08",
      "dateModified": "2025-01-08",
      "image": "https://www.switchbacktravel.com/sites/default/files/image_fields/In-Depth%20Gear%20Reviews/Salomon%20Cross%20Hike%202%20Mid%20GTX/%E2%80%8B%E2%80%8BSalomon%20Cross%20Hike%202%20Mid%20GTX%20hiking%20boots%20%28backpacking%20in%20Patagonia%29.jpg",
      "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",
        "@id": "https://explorenationalparks.store/salomon-cross-hike-gtx"
      },
      "publisher": {
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "Explore National Parks"
      },
      "keywords": ["Salomon Cross Hike GTX", "hiking boots", "Gore-Tex", "outdoor gear", "hiking review"],
      "wordCount": 2800,
      "articleSection": "Gear Reviews",
      "mainEntity": {
        "@type": "FAQPage",
        "mainEntity": [
          {
            "@type": "Question",
            "name": "Are Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots good for beginners?",
            "acceptedAnswer": {
              "@type": "Answer",
              "text": "Yes, the Salomon Cross Hike GTX is excellent for beginners. The lightweight design requires minimal break-in time, and the Gore-Tex waterproofing provides reliable protection. The boots offer good traction on various terrains and are comfortable for day hikes. However, beginners should be aware that these boots provide limited ankle support compared to traditional hiking boots, so they're best suited for well-maintained trails and moderate terrain."
            }
          },
          {
            "@type": "Question",
            "name": "How waterproof are the Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots?",
            "acceptedAnswer": {
              "@type": "Answer",
              "text": "The Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots feature Gore-Tex waterproofing, which provides excellent water resistance for stream crossings, wet grass, and light rain. In my testing, they kept my feet dry during puddle crossings and hiking in wet conditions. However, some users report issues with water entering through the collar in deep puddles or extended exposure to water. The Gore-Tex membrane is breathable but can feel warm in hot weather."
            }
          },
          {
            "@type": "Question",
            "name": "What's the difference between Cross Hike GTX and Cross Hike 2 GTX?",
            "acceptedAnswer": {
              "@type": "Answer",
              "text": "The Cross Hike 2 GTX is the updated version with several improvements: enhanced tread pattern with more lugs extending over the toe box for better uphill traction, increased stack height (7mm taller) for more cushioning, improved upper materials, and better overall durability. The Cross Hike 2 also features a slightly higher collar for better debris protection. Both versions use Gore-Tex waterproofing and have similar lightweight construction."
            }
          },
          {
            "@type": "Question",
            "name": "How does the sizing run for Salomon Cross Hike GTX?",
            "acceptedAnswer": {
              "@type": "Answer",
              "text": "Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots generally run true to size, but they have a snug heel and narrow toe box typical of Salomon footwear. For standard to narrow feet, order your normal hiking boot size. Wide-footed hikers may need to size up half to one full size or consider the wide versions available for the Cross Hike 2. The boots have minimal break-in time, so proper initial fit is crucial for comfort."
            }
          },
          {
            "@type": "Question",
            "name": "Can you run in Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots?",
            "acceptedAnswer": {
              "@type": "Answer",
              "text": "Yes, you can run short distances in the Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots due to their lightweight, running shoe-like feel. The EnergyCell midsole provides good energy return and cushioning. However, they're primarily designed for hiking rather than running. For extended running, dedicated trail running shoes would be more appropriate. The boots work well for hikers who occasionally need to pick up the pace or navigate technical terrain quickly."
            }
          },
          {
            "@type": "Question",
            "name": "What type of terrain are Cross Hike GTX boots best for?",
            "acceptedAnswer": {
              "@type": "Answer",
              "text": "The Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots excel on dirt trails, sandy surfaces, gravel paths, and muddy conditions. The Contagrip outsole provides excellent traction on soft surfaces and variable terrain. They perform well on moderate inclines and declines. However, they're less ideal for technical rock climbing, extensive boulder hopping, or very rugged terrain where more ankle support would be beneficial. Best suited for day hikes and well-maintained trails."
            }
          }
        ]
      }
    }
    </script>

body:
Salomon Cross Hike GTX Review: The Ultimate Hiking Boot Guide 2025

After two years of testing the Salomon Cross Hike GTX across diverse terrains from New Mexico's desert trails to Pennsylvania's rocky paths, I've compiled this comprehensive guide. These lightweight, versatile boots blur the line between trail runners and traditional hiking boots, offering unique advantages for modern adventurers. Discover everything you need to know about this popular hiking footwear. Explore more gear reviews at our homepage.

Table of Contents

  1. What Makes the Salomon Cross Hike GTX Special?
  2. My Personal Experience with the Cross Hike GTX
  3. Detailed Performance Analysis
  4. User Reviews and Real-World Feedback
  5. Pros and Cons: The Complete Breakdown
  6. Buying Guide and Alternatives
  7. Conclusion
  8. Frequently Asked Questions

What Makes the Salomon Cross Hike GTX Special?

The Salomon Cross Hike GTX represents a fascinating evolution in hiking footwear, positioned perfectly between lightweight trail runners and traditional hiking boots. What sets these boots apart is their unique approach to outdoor versatility—they're designed for hikers who want the protection and waterproofing of a boot with the agility and comfort of a running shoe.

The standout feature is undoubtedly the Gore-Tex waterproofing system, which provides reliable protection against water while maintaining breathability. Unlike many waterproof boots that feel stuffy, the Cross Hike GTX manages moisture well during moderate activity levels. The cross hike shoe design philosophy emphasizes minimal weight without sacrificing essential protection.

The Contagrip outsole deserves special mention—it's engineered with multi-directional lugs that excel on soft surfaces like dirt, sand, and mud. The tread pattern extends onto the toe box, providing extra grip when climbing steep sections. This attention to traction detail makes the Salomon Cross Hike GTX particularly effective on variable terrain where conditions change rapidly.

Construction-wise, these boots feature a seamless upper design that reduces hot spots and pressure points. The EnergyCell midsole technology provides responsive cushioning that feels more dynamic than traditional hiking boot foams. At just over 2 pounds for a men's size 12, they're significantly lighter than conventional mid-cut hiking boots, making them ideal for fast-paced day hikes and approach situations.

Key Innovation: The Cross Hike GTX bridges the gap between urban and wilderness use, making it equally suitable for city walks and trail adventures—a versatility that traditional hiking boots rarely achieve.

My Personal Experience with the Cross Hike GTX

I've put these boots through their paces across diverse environments, from the sandy arroyos of Albuquerque to the rocky trails of Pennsylvania's state parks. My first impression was how remarkably lightweight they felt—almost like wearing athletic shoes rather than hiking boots. This became both a blessing and a limitation depending on the terrain.

During my initial test hike on New Mexico's Piedra Lisa Trail, the boots performed exceptionally well on the gravelly, steep sections where many hikers struggle with footing. The extended toe lugs provided confidence-inspiring grip on loose rock and sandy surfaces. However, I noticed the collar's tendency to collect small debris—a design quirk that became more apparent on longer hikes.

Seasonal Performance Insights

Fall hiking in Pennsylvania revealed both strengths and weaknesses. On wet leaves and muddy sections along Spring Creek, the Gore-Tex kept my feet completely dry, even during stream crossings. The breathability was impressive for a waterproof boot—I rarely experienced the swampy feeling common with cheaper waterproof footwear. However, the narrow toe box became problematic during longer hikes when my feet swelled.

Winter testing presented interesting challenges. In shallow snow and on hardpack trails, the Salomon Cross Hike Mid GTX performed admirably. The insulation properties were adequate for temperatures down to about 25°F with appropriate socks. However, the collar design allowed snow infiltration during deeper snow conditions—a limitation that traditional high-cut boots handle better.

One memorable experience was a fast-paced scramble up Tres Pistoles Trail near Albuquerque. The lightweight nature of these boots really shined during technical sections where agility mattered more than ankle support. I could move quickly over loose rock and navigate narrow ledges with confidence. The responsive midsole provided excellent energy return during the steep ascent, making the climb feel less taxing than in heavier boots.

Check Latest Price on Amazon

Detailed Performance Analysis

After extensive field testing, I can break down the performance characteristics into key areas that matter most to hikers. The Salomon Cross Hike GTX excels in some areas while showing limitations in others—understanding these nuances is crucial for making the right purchase decision.

Traction and Stability

The Contagrip outsole truly shines on soft surfaces. I've tested these boots on sandy desert washes, muddy forest trails, and loose gravel slopes with consistently impressive results. The lug pattern is aggressive enough to bite into soft terrain but spaced well to shed mud effectively. However, performance on wet rock is more limited—the compound doesn't provide the same confidence on slick surfaces that dedicated approach shoes offer.

Stability-wise, the Salomon Cross Hike 2 version addresses some concerns from the original with improved midsole support. The hidden chassis provides torsional rigidity without adding significant weight, though ankle support remains minimal compared to traditional hiking boots.

Comfort and Fit Characteristics

Comfort is where these boots really differentiate themselves. The running shoe-like feel becomes apparent immediately—there's virtually no break-in period required. The EVA insole provides excellent cushioning, and the EnergyCell midsole offers responsive energy return that reduces fatigue on long ascents.

Fit follows typical Salomon patterns: snug heel, average midfoot, narrow toe box. This works well for standard to narrow feet but can be problematic for wide-footed hikers. I found sizing up half a size helped with toe box comfort during longer hikes, though this compromised some heel security.

The quicklace system is both convenient and frustrating. While easy to adjust on the trail, the laces are excessively long and prone to working out of their storage pocket—a safety concern in technical terrain. Traditional laces would provide better customization and security, though they'd sacrifice the convenience factor that makes these boots appealing for casual use.

User Reviews and Real-World Feedback

To provide a balanced perspective, I've analyzed feedback from hundreds of users across various platforms. The consensus reveals both passionate advocates and disappointed customers, with experiences varying significantly based on intended use and foot shape compatibility.

Positive User Experience - REI Customer

"Great shoe, good traction, and secure footing. Light and very comfortable. Looks good, feels good. I've been using these for day hikes in Colorado and they handle rocky trails surprisingly well. The Gore-Tex has kept my feet dry through several stream crossings."

User Profile: Day hiker, moderate terrain, size 12 men's

Mixed Experience - Amazon Reviewer

"Purchased these shoes to climb one of the seven summits. They seem very comfortable from the get-go, no break-in required. Ample support and adequate sole stiffness. The trouble started after the first drizzle hit the trail. After only 5 minutes of walking, I noticed the entire GORE-TEX portion was soaking wet with a noticeable decrease of insulation properties."

User Profile: Technical climbing, extreme conditions, size 11 men's

Negative Experience - Reddit User

"On day two of my first backpacking trip, my foot punched a hole through the Gore-Tex upper of the toe box. I have wide feet, but it seems like a pair of shoes should last more than 48 hours. I also found these shoes to be very heavy and not at all breathable. My feet were sweaty the whole trip, and I ended up with blisters."

User Profile: Backpacker, wide feet, size 12 men's

Common Themes from User Feedback

Analyzing patterns across reviews reveals several consistent themes. Positive experiences typically come from day hikers using the boots on well-maintained trails with moderate loads. Users praise the comfort, lightweight feel, and adequate waterproofing for typical hiking conditions. The Salomon Cross Hike Mid GTX hiking boots receive particular praise from urban hikers who appreciate the versatile styling.

Negative experiences cluster around several issues: durability concerns with the synthetic upper materials, inadequate ankle support for technical terrain, and fit problems for wide feet. Several users reported premature wear on the toe box and concerns about long-term durability. The quicklace system receives mixed reviews, with many users finding the excessive length annoying and potentially dangerous.

Interestingly, the Gore-Tex performance shows mixed results. While most users report good waterproofing in typical conditions, some experience premature failure or inadequate protection in extreme conditions. This suggests quality control variations or different expectations about waterproof performance limits.

Shop Women's Cross Hike GTX

Pros and Cons: The Complete Breakdown

After extensive testing and analysis of user feedback, I can provide a comprehensive breakdown of the Salomon Cross Hike GTX's strengths and limitations. This balanced perspective will help you determine if these boots align with your hiking style and needs.

Advantages

  • Exceptional lightweight design - At 2 pounds, they feel more like athletic shoes than hiking boots
  • Superior traction on soft surfaces - Excellent grip on dirt, sand, gravel, and muddy terrain
  • Minimal break-in period - Comfortable immediately out of the box
  • Reliable Gore-Tex waterproofing - Keeps feet dry in typical wet conditions
  • Versatile urban/trail design - Suitable for both city walking and hiking
  • Responsive midsole cushioning - EnergyCell technology provides good energy return
  • Quick-drying materials - Synthetic construction dries faster than leather

Limitations

  • Limited ankle support - Mid-cut design offers minimal stability enhancement
  • Durability concerns - Some users report premature upper material failure
  • Narrow toe box - Challenging fit for wide-footed hikers
  • Poor rock traction - Less effective on wet or smooth stone surfaces
  • Problematic quicklaces - Excessively long laces create tripping hazard
  • Debris infiltration - Collar design allows small rocks and sand entry
  • Limited load capacity - Not ideal for heavy backpacking loads

When These Boots Excel vs. Fall Short

The Salomon Cross Hike GTX performs best for day hikers tackling well-maintained trails with moderate elevation gain. They're particularly effective for fast-paced hiking, approach situations, and mixed urban/trail use. The boots shine in conditions where agility matters more than maximum protection—think desert washes, forest paths, and groomed park trails.

These boots struggle in technical terrain requiring significant ankle support, extended backpacking with heavy loads, and conditions where maximum durability is essential. Rocky scrambling, off-trail bushwhacking, and multi-day treks expose the limitations of the lightweight construction. The Salomon Cross Hike Mid GTX hiking boots men's version shares these characteristics across the gender-specific models.

Weather performance is nuanced—excellent for typical hiking conditions with light rain or snow, but less reliable in extreme conditions or extended water exposure. The breathable Gore-Tex works well for moderate activity levels but can feel warm during intense summer hiking or high-output activities.

Bottom Line: These boots represent an excellent choice for hikers prioritizing comfort and versatility over maximum protection and durability. They're ideal for the growing segment of casual and urban hikers but may disappoint those seeking traditional hiking boot performance.

Buying Guide and Alternatives

Choosing the right hiking footwear requires matching your specific needs to the boot's capabilities. The Salomon Cross Hike GTX occupies a unique niche that serves certain hikers exceptionally well while disappointing others. Understanding where you fit in this spectrum is crucial for making the right decision.

Sizing and Fit Recommendations

Proper sizing is critical with the Cross Hike GTX due to the narrow toe box and running shoe-like construction. For standard to narrow feet, order your typical hiking boot size. The snug heel cup will prevent forward sliding even in your normal size. Wide-footed hikers should consider sizing up half to one full size, though this may compromise heel security.

Try the boots in the afternoon when your feet have swelled to their largest daily size. Walk around the store for at least 10 minutes to assess comfort, particularly in the toe box area. The Salomon Cross Hike Mid GTX hiking boots women's version runs similarly to the men's but may have slightly more generous toe box proportions.

Consider your sock preferences when sizing. Thicker hiking socks may require going up half a size, while thin synthetic socks work well with true-to-size fitting. The minimal break-in period means your initial fit assessment is crucial—what feels right in the store will largely remain the same after purchase.

Men's Cross Hike 2 GTX

Latest version with improved tread and durability

Check Price on Amazon

Women's Cross Hike GTX

Original version, often available at discounted prices

Shop Women's Version

Alternative Recommendations

If the Cross Hike GTX doesn't match your needs, several alternatives offer different trade-offs. The Salomon X Ultra 4 Mid GTX provides more traditional hiking boot support with only a slight weight penalty. For those wanting maximum durability, the Salomon Quest 4 GTX offers bombproof construction at the cost of added weight and bulk.

For hikers prioritizing breathability over waterproofing, consider the non-GTX versions of these boots. They'll dry faster after water exposure but offer no protection against rain or stream crossings. The Salomon Cross Hike shoes low-cut version provides similar traction and comfort with less ankle coverage.

Outside the Salomon ecosystem, the Hoka Anacapa Mid GTX offers similar lightweight construction with better cushioning for those with joint issues. The Merrell Moab 3 Mid provides a more affordable option with traditional hiking boot feel but significantly more weight.

Pro Tip: Consider buying during seasonal sales or end-of-model-year clearances. Hiking boots often see significant discounts in late winter and early spring as retailers clear inventory for new models.

Conclusion

The Salomon Cross Hike GTX represents a thoughtful evolution in hiking footwear, successfully bridging the gap between athletic shoes and traditional hiking boots. After extensive testing across diverse terrains and conditions, I can confidently say these boots excel in their intended niche while falling short in areas requiring maximum support or durability.

These boots are ideal for day hikers, urban adventurers, and anyone prioritizing comfort and versatility over maximum protection. The lightweight construction, reliable Gore-Tex waterproofing, and excellent soft-surface traction make them particularly suitable for well-maintained trails, mixed urban/trail use, and fast-paced hiking scenarios.

However, they're not the right choice for everyone. Hikers needing significant ankle support, those planning extended backpacking trips with heavy loads, or adventurers tackling consistently technical terrain should look elsewhere. The durability concerns and narrow fit also limit their appeal for certain users.

The Cross Hike GTX succeeds by focusing on the growing segment of hikers who want hiking capability without hiking boot compromises. They offer enough protection and performance for serious outdoor use while maintaining the comfort and styling that appeals to casual users. This makes them particularly relevant as outdoor activities become more mainstream and accessible.

For the right hiker, the Salomon Cross Hike GTX provides an excellent balance of performance, comfort, and versatility. Understanding your priorities and hiking style is key to determining if these boots match your needs. The Salomon Cross Hike GTX continues to evolve with each iteration, addressing user feedback while maintaining the core characteristics that make them appealing to their target audience.

Explore All Cross Hike GTX Options

Frequently Asked Questions

Are Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots good for beginners?

Yes, the Salomon Cross Hike GTX is excellent for beginners. The lightweight design requires minimal break-in time, and the Gore-Tex waterproofing provides reliable protection. The boots offer good traction on various terrains and are comfortable for day hikes. However, beginners should be aware that these boots provide limited ankle support compared to traditional hiking boots, so they're best suited for well-maintained trails and moderate terrain. The running shoe-like feel makes them less intimidating for new hikers transitioning from athletic shoes.

How waterproof are the Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots?

The Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots feature Gore-Tex waterproofing, which provides excellent water resistance for stream crossings, wet grass, and light rain. In my testing, they kept my feet dry during puddle crossings and hiking in wet conditions. However, some users report issues with water entering through the collar in deep puddles or extended exposure to water. The Gore-Tex membrane is breathable but can feel warm in hot weather. The waterproofing is reliable for typical hiking conditions but has limits in extreme situations or with prolonged water exposure.

What's the difference between Cross Hike GTX and Cross Hike 2 GTX?

The Cross Hike 2 GTX is the updated version with several improvements: enhanced tread pattern with more lugs extending over the toe box for better uphill traction, increased stack height (7mm taller) for more cushioning, improved upper materials, and better overall durability. The Cross Hike 2 also features a slightly higher collar for better debris protection. Both versions use Gore-Tex waterproofing and have similar lightweight construction. The Cross Hike 2 addresses many user complaints from the original version while maintaining the core design philosophy.

How does the sizing run for Salomon Cross Hike GTX?

Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots generally run true to size, but they have a snug heel and narrow toe box typical of Salomon footwear. For standard to narrow feet, order your normal hiking boot size. Wide-footed hikers may need to size up half to one full size or consider the wide versions available for the Cross Hike 2. The boots have minimal break-in time, so proper initial fit is crucial for comfort. Try them on in the afternoon when feet are naturally swollen, and consider your sock thickness preferences when selecting size.

Can you run in Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots?

Yes, you can run short distances in the Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots due to their lightweight, running shoe-like feel. The EnergyCell midsole provides good energy return and cushioning. However, they're primarily designed for hiking rather than running. For extended running, dedicated trail running shoes would be more appropriate. The boots work well for hikers who occasionally need to pick up the pace or navigate technical terrain quickly. The responsive midsole and lightweight construction make them suitable for fast-paced hiking and approach situations where agility matters.

What type of terrain are Cross Hike GTX boots best for?

The Salomon Cross Hike GTX boots excel on dirt trails, sandy surfaces, gravel paths, and muddy conditions. The Contagrip outsole provides excellent traction on soft surfaces and variable terrain. They perform well on moderate inclines and declines. However, they're less ideal for technical rock climbing, extensive boulder hopping, or very rugged terrain where more ankle support would be beneficial. Best suited for day hikes and well-maintained trails. The tread pattern is specifically designed for mixed terrain but shows limitations on wet rock or highly technical surfaces requiring maximum grip and support.

Ready to Hit the Trails?
